markdownRemark.html:
Around the start of the year, I decided I wanted to contribute to Open Source.

I remembered reading about first time PRs and came across these two resources. Both looked promising, and I figured I’d start with Ruby, since that was the language I had most experience with.

The first project I tried submitting a PR for was Rails (that would be something nice on the resume). I searched for a first timers tag, spent a Saturday working on it, submitted it!

Then I waited.

And waited.

After a month or so, I decided I would try to contribute elsewhere. There was a tool we were using at work, we wanted a feature and there was an issue for it, so I spent a few weeknights and weekends learning Go, doing up the PR and submitting it.

Then I waited.

And someone reviewed! I was energised. I made some changes. Then he requested a second opinion from another maintainer.

It’s still there, open.

By this point I was quite disheartened. No hate to open source maintainers, it’s pretty thankless work and the world is better for their contributions. Still.

I flapped around a bit, before looking at another repo, another tool that our company had been using. This time I saw a pretty steady stream of merges, the issues were labelled nicely, and it wasn’t as intimidating as Rails was.

A few days later, my first merge!

I was elated. Huge props to dblock, who is pretty on the ball in reviewing and merging.

Rubyists, if you would love to contribute but don’t know where to, might I humbly suggest anyone of dblock’s projects - it’s a great place to start.
